alert.note: Alert for Fremont (Colorado) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued June 06 at 4:04PM MDT until June 06 at 7:00PM MDT by NWS Pueblo
info.description: The National Weather Service in Pueblo has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... The Hayden Pass Burn Scar in... Southwestern Fremont County in central Colorado... * Until 700 PM MDT. * At 404 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain over the Hayden Pass Burn Scar. Up to 0.5 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 2 inches in 1 hour. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will result in debris flow moving through the South Prong Creek, Hayden Creek, Wolf Creek, and Cottonwood Creek. The debris flow can consist of rock, mud, vegetation and other loose materials. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding in and around the Hayden Pass Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Hayden Pass Burn Scar. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Hayden Pass Burn Scar. This includes the following high risk locations... Cutty`s Resort On Hayden Creek Road and Big Cottonwood Creek along County Road 40. This includes the following streams and drainages... Arkansas River, Big Cottonwood Creek, Middle Prong Creek, Hayden Creek, Little Cottonwood Creek, and Hayden Pass Creek. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...2 INCHES IN 1 HOUR
info.instruction: This is a life threatening situation. Heavy rainfall will cause extensive and severe flash flooding of creeks...streams...and ditches in the Hayden Pass Burn Scar. Severe debris flows can also be anticipated across roads. Roads and driveways may be washed away in places. If you encounter flood waters...climb to safety. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
